metaData.descriptionCS: The child answers questions based on his or her understanding of general principles and social situations.

questions.title: †Item 1. Teeth
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why do people brush their teeth?

General concept: Recognition that brushing one’s teeth cleans the teeth; or prevents decay, disease, cavities, and other dental problems

answers.html: It’s good
It’s gross if you don’t
If you (eat candy, drink pop, drink soda)
(Have, Supposed) to; Do it every day
Their parents tell them to
They ate too much candy
So they (stay white, won’t turn yellow)
So your smile looks (better, prettier)
It’s good for (them, teeth, gums, your mouth)
So teeth don’t get (damaged, hurt)
To keep breath (fresh, smelling good)
Keeps your teeth from falling out; So you don’t (lose your teeth, need false teeth)
Keeps you from having to see the dentist; So dentist bill isn’t high
To prevent (cavities, gum disease)
Keeps (plaque, tartar) from building up
To keep (them, your mouth) clean; So they aren’t dirty
To (kill, get rid of) germs (on teeth, in your mouth)
So your (teeth, gums) stay healthy
So your teeth will be (stronger, in better condition)
So your teeth will not (decay, rot)
Protects your teeth
It’s (good hygiene, hygienic)

questions.title: †Item 2. Vegetables
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why should people eat vegetables?

General concept: Recognition that vegetables are part of a nutritious diet or are necessary for proper health, growth, strength, or energy

answers.html: Because they’re hungry
They’re good; They taste good
Eating (candy, junk food) makes you sick
To look good
Prevent death; To stay alive
Gain weight
To get dessert
Parents say so
For (strength, energy)
They help you
To (grow, get big, get bigger)
(Help, Good for) your (eyes, bones, [names specific body part])
Lose weight; To be thin; Weight control
(Help, Good for) your (vision, digestion, memory, [names specific body function])
Prevents problems with (cramps, upset stomach)
Prevents (heart attacks, cancer, [names specific ailment])
Help you see better
So you can see in the dark
They’re (healthy, good for you)
Contain (vitamins, nutrients, fiber, things our body needs)
It’s healthy; Keeps you healthy
They help your body
For a balanced diet; To eat from each food group
Prevent disease
To grow big and strong; To give you strength and energy; To make you (strong, energized)

questions.title: †Item 3. Seatbelts
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why do cars have seatbelts?

General concept: Recognition that seatbelts are safety precautions to protect people from harm when an accident (stated or strongly implied) takes place, or to restrain them in an accident

answers.html: So you won’t get in a car accident
Locks you in; Keeps you locked in
So you can wear them
Goes across your chest or lap
Parents make me
For (safety, protection); To be safe; It’s a safety precaution; [Refers to safety without reference to accident]
So you don’t (get hurt, hit your head, get bruised); [Refers to injury without reference to accident]
In case of a(n) (accident, wreck, car crash); [Refers to accident without reference to safety]
(Holds, Restrains) you; (Holds, Keeps) you in place
Can save (you, your life); Saves lives of others
In case someone (stops short, brakes quickly)
So you don’t (fly, fall) out
It’s the law; So you don’t get (a ticket, pulled over)
To prevent people from getting hurt in an accident; Reduce injury in a wreck
(Holds, Restrains) you in an accident
To keep people safe in an accident; To protect people in a(n) (accident, wreck)
So you don’t hit the (dash, steering wheel, windshield); So you don’t fly out the windshield
Can save (you, your life) in an accident
So you don’t get hurt if someone (stops short, brakes quickly)
So you don’t (fly, fall) out in an accident

questions.title: †Item 4. Wallet
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What should you do if you find someone’s wallet or purse in a store?

General concept: Recognition that it should be returned to the owner and a description of appropriate action to take

answers.html: Give it to my (mom, dad)
Ask store employee if it’s theirs
Don’t keep it
Pick it up
Shout; Tell them
Give it to the postman; Drop it in a mailbox
Throw it away
Keep it; See how much money is in it
Leave it (there, alone); Put it back; Take no action
Check for (ID, identification, name, phone number)
Take it to the police
Try to find the owner
Give it back; Return it
Announce it on the loudspeaker
Ask people nearby if it's theirs; Hand it back if they dropped it
Take it to their house; Call them
Put it on a flyer; Put it in the newspaper
Check for (ID, identification) and (return it to them, call them)
(Mail it, Take it to their house) if there is (an ID, identification)
Try to find who it belongs to and return it; Find them and give it back
Turn it in; Turn it in to the (counter, Lost and Found, cashier, security guard)
Give it to my mom and she’ll find the owner
Take it to the police and they’ll find the owner

questions.title: §Item 5. Smoke
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What should you do if you see thick smoke coming from your neighbor’s house?

answers.text: Call (the operator, 311)
Go next door
Run away
Yell “Fire”
Break a window to let smoke out
Close the windows
Don’t breathe the smoke
Panic
Put the fire out
Stop, drop, and roll
Wait for the firemen
Call 911; Report to (fire, police) department
Set off the fire alarm; Pull down handle in fire box
Ask adult to call (fire, police) department
Call the dispatcher and (answer questions, give them the address)
Drive to (fire, police) station and tell them

answerGroups.answersExplanation: Recognition that appropriate emergency services, such as the fire or police departments, should be notified
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Response reflects one of the general concepts

answers.text: Call for help; (Get, Go) help; Help them
Tell my (mom, dad); Get parents to (help, check it out); [References notifying adult]
Warn neighbors; Bang on door and tell them that their house is on fire
Get them out of the house; See if everyone is out; [References evacuating others]
Go see if they’re OK; Check on the neighbors; [Verify safety of others]
Get everyone out of your house because it could catch fire; [References evacuating your own house]
Go see what’s wrong; Make sure (it isn’t barbecue, there’s really a fire)
Stay away
Get a (fire extinguisher, water hose)
Stay away so you won’t (get hurt, breathe smoke)

answerGroups.answersExplanation: Identification of an appropriate activity to perform until emergency services arrive
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Response reflects both of the general concepts

scoreList.label: Response reflects one of the general concepts
Response reflects both of the general concepts

questions.title: Item 6. Cell phones
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why do some teachers not allow students to use their cell phones during class?

General concept: Recognition that cell phones are a distraction in the classroom

answers.html: Makes it harder for teachers to teach; Because they’re teaching
They think they shouldn’t have (them, cell phones)
They (make noise, vibrate)
Because (the teacher, the principal, mom, dad) doesn’t like it
Because class is not as (interesting, fun) as your cell phone
Students might (make calls, take pictures)
Phones might get (lost, stolen)
Could cause (cyber-bullying, fights)
Limits participation; Keeps students from participating; [No reference to learning]
(They, Students) might miss (directions, instructions)
It keeps them from learning; It’s harder for students to learn
Interruption; Interrupts the class
Students might (send texts, search the Internet, use the calculator)
To listen; So students can (listen, hear)
Might (bother, annoy) (others, other students); It’s (rude, disrespectful)
Not fair to students that don’t have them; Some students don’t have cell phones
Students might (make calls, take pictures) so they can (cheat, do better than other students)
(Might, Could) take pictures of (answers, tests)
So students (pay attention to, concentrate on) learning; So they pay attention
Students might (be distracted, not pay attention); Students may pay more attention to their phones
Limits participation in learning
Distraction; Distracts them

questions.title: §Item 7. Lights
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Why should you turn the lights off when no one is using them?

answers.text: So you don’t (start a fire, burn the house down)
So power lines don’t explode; So lightning doesn’t hit you
Might blow a fuse; Light bulb could explode
Your parents get mad if you don’t
It’s safer; People can’t see inside
Someone might rob your house
So you don’t waste electricity; To save (electricity, fuel, power, energy)
So we don’t run out of power; So power won’t (go, run) out
You might need electricity in the future and would not have any left
To conserve energy

answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Response reflects one of the general concepts

answers.text: So you don’t run up the electric bill; Otherwise the bill would be high
Will use up light bulbs; Light bulb could (go, burn) out
To save money; Won’t have to pay as much; Wastes money
So the (lights don’t, electricity doesn't) get (cut, turned) off
Costs a lot of money to burn them; Costs money
So (the electric company doesn’t, they don’t) turn the (lights, power) off
To decrease pollution; It’s bad for the environment if you don’t
To save the battery

answerGroups.answersExplanation:
Recognition that it conserves financial or
environmental resources
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Response reflects both of the general concepts

scoreList.label: Response reflects one of the general concepts
Response reflects both of the general concepts

questions.title: Item 8. Calendars
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why do people use calendars?

General concept: Recognition that calendars facilitate the organization of activities or maintenance of a schedule

answers.html: To write stuff down; To write notes on it
So they (remember, don’t forget)
To be on time; So they aren’t late
So they (remember, don’t forget, know) the (week, month, year)
To keep track of time
They like the pictures; To hang in their locker; To put stickers in it
To (be, stay) organized; To stay on track
So they (remember, don’t forget) to (go to the doctor, take out the trash, [describes specific activity])
So they (remember, don’t forget, know) the (day, date); To (know, keep track of) (what day it is, the date)
They are using their planner
So they (know, see) what to do
So they know where (they’re going, to go)
So they (remember, don’t forget, know) (holidays, birthdays, special days)
To (schedule, organize, keep track of, plan) (meetings, events, appointments, activities, things you have to do, [describes general activity])
So they (remember, don’t forget, don’t miss) (meetings, events, appointments, activities, things they have to do, [describes general activity])
So they don’t (double book, schedule something) at the same time
So they can prioritize what they need to do; So they can make sure they do the important things
To (maintain, organize, keep track of, plan) their schedule
To (plan, plan ahead); For planning

questions.title: Item 9. Chores
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why is it good for children to do chores?

General concept: Recognition that chores develop responsibility or allow children to contribute to the family’s well-being

answers.html: It’s your job
To (get an allowance, make money); So they earn their (allowance, own money)
So your parents don’t punish you; Get in trouble if you don’t
To learn how to (do laundry, keep the house clean)
It’s good for (you, them); Good for kids to help out
So the (house is clean, yard looks nice)
Because you have to; You have to do chores
(For, To learn) discipline; So you learn how to follow (rules, directions)
Helps you later in life; So you know what to do when you grow up
To help (their parents, the family); Parents (work, can’t do it all)
To learn how to do things; Teaches you how to do things; To learn skills
So they (get something done, are productive)
So they (aren’t lazy, don’t sit around and watch TV)
It’s your responsibility
Builds character
So they (stay out of trouble, keep busy)
So they learn responsibility; Teaches responsibility
Builds a good work ethic; Teaches the value of hard work
So the child (contributes, gives back) to the family; So the child is a productive family member
So everyone (helps, contributes to) the family
Teaches you independence; So they learn how to be independent
To learn how to do things (for yourself, when you grow up)
To (learn discipline and help the family); So (you aren’t lazy and it helps you later in life); [Provides two good examples]
To learn future life skills
Can help you in your future employment

questions.title: Item 10. Brag
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why is it bad to brag about yourself?

General concept: Recognition that boasting about yourself is self-centered or that it may be insensitive to those who are less fortunate

answers.html: People will think you’re (mean, not nice)
People (are, will be) jealous of you
You could (get into a fight, make people mad)
People will think you’re (cool, strong, fast)
It’s (mean, not nice)
People don’t like it when you act like you are (special, great, hot)
It’s (rude, impolite, bad manners, annoying)
You will seem like you need attention
It hurts other people's feelings; It can make others feel bad
People (won’t like you, won’t want to be your friend)
Others (don’t, might not) have (the same things, what you have)
People will think you’re a boaster; You’ll seem like a show-off
It’s (arrogant, conceited, snobby, prideful)
It’s (selfish, self-centered)
It (seems, appears, looks) like you think you’re better than other people
It isn’t modest
It makes others feel bad about (themselves, their situation, how things are for them)
People won’t (like you, want to be your friend) because you seem (selfish, snobby, like you only care about yourself)
Others may not be as fortunate as you are; Others may not have as much as you do
You’ll seem like a show-off and (it might hurt others’ feelings, others won’t want to be your friend)
People will think you’re (rude, annoying) because you (only talk about yourself, act like you’re better than them)

questions.title: Item 11. Door
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What does this saying mean? “Teachers open the door, but you must enter.”

General concept: Recognition that learning is the individual’s responsibility even though teachers can provide learning opportunities; or that it is the individual’s responsibility to take opportunities they are presented with

answers.html: You have to go to teachers, they won’t come to you
You have to do it
Teachers won’t pass you if you don’t (study, come to class)
Teachers will hold the door if you’re carrying books; [Provides literal interpretation]
You need to have teachers
Teachers can’t (make you, force you to) learn
You have to (work, study) hard
Teachers give you (assignments, tests, homework), but you have to do it
Teachers can’t do (it all, everything) for you
You have to (do the work, learn)
A teacher’s gift is a willing student; [Provides analogous proverb or saying]
You’re the one responsible for (learning, your education); [Must reference responsibility]
You can be (given, presented with) opportunities but you (choose whether, have) to take them
Teachers can only teach you so much if you don’t (try, work hard, study)
Teachers (teach, give you information), but you have to (do the learning, be willing to learn)
Teachers can (help you, help you learn) if you let them
You have to (try, make an effort) to learn yourself

questions.title: Item 12. Field trips
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why do students go on field trips?

General concept: Recognition that field trips provide an opportunity for experiential learning

answers.html: To see (things, the sights)
As a reward for being good
So they make better grades
To go to (museums, the zoo); [Describes a specific field trip]
(Class, School) is boring; To get (away from, out of) (school, learning)
To learn about (dinosaurs, animals, [describes specific subject potentially the focus of a field trip])
They’re fun
To (ride on the bus, spend time with friends)
To learn more; To learn more than what we do in (class, school)
They help make you more well-rounded
To (learn, see) something new
So you can see (neat, interesting) things
So they are smarter
To learn stuff in different places
To (discover, explore) things
To learn things; To learn
To make learning more (interesting, fun)
Because (experiencing, being there for) something teaches you things you can’t learn in (class, school)
(Doing, Experiencing) something gives you (more, different, new) information than (reading, learning) about it
(Doing, Experiencing) things they (learn, read, write) about makes them remember it better; It (helps them remember, reinforces) what they learn at school
To learn about the real world; So you can learn through real-world experience
To (experience, learn) things that can’t be (taught, learned) in (school, class)
So they can get (real-world, actual, real) experience
To learn by doing something

questions.title: Item 13. Plans
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why should you keep plans that you make with other people?

General concept: Recognition that following through on plans is a sign of dependability, trustworthiness, or conscientiousness; or shows consideration of others’ feelings

answers.html: If you don’t, they might not (invite you anymore, want to do stuff with you, [no reference to loss of relationship])
They may get (mad, angry)
If you don’t, they might think you don’t want to do stuff with them
You could miss something fun
You said you would go
You might miss the (concert, movie, show, [describes specific event])
It’s (mean, not nice)
If you don’t, (you might lose friends, they may not want to be your friend)
It’s (impolite, rude) not to; It’s polite
They might miss the (concert, movie, show, [describes specific event])
Missed opportunities; Might miss something important
To keep a commitment; You made a commitment
May not get to see them (again, for a long time)
To keep your (promise, word); You gave them your word
You might hurt their feelings; They may feel (hurt, sad, disappointed)
If you don’t, they’ll (just be waiting, be all alone)
So others know you’re (dependable, reliable, trustworthy)
It is inconvenient to others if you don’t
So others know you (can be counted on, mean what you say, follow through, keep your word)
It’s (inconsiderate, thoughtless, selfish) not to
Someone is (expecting, counting on) you
Shows you’re (conscientious, concerned about others)
They might stop (trusting, believing) you
It’s rude to the other people if you don’t; It’s (unfair, rude) to others not to
If you don’t, (their plans are ruined too, you waste their time); [Describes specific impact to other person]

questions.title: Item 14. Truth
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why should people tell the truth?

General concept: Recognition that honesty builds trust in relationships

answers.html: So you don’t (lie, tell a lie)
It’s the right thing to do
You may not remember what (you said, the lie was); Makes it hard to keep track of what you said
Because it is (wrong, bad) to lie; Lying is bad; Lying is dishonest
Honesty is the best policy; You should be honest
It’s lying if you don’t
It’s (polite, good manners, rude to lie)
The truth will set you free
People get mad at you if you lie
So you don’t get (in trouble, punished)
So you can (make, keep) friends; People won’t be your friend
So (they, people) (believe you, know what you are saying is true, know you aren’t lying)
One lie leads to more lies; You just have to tell more lies
Lies can hurt people
Because [names religious figure] says not to lie
Telling the truth allows you to get (it, the weight) off your (chest, shoulders, conscience)
Relationships are built on (trust, honesty, being able to believe what the other person is saying)
So people trust you; People stop trusting you if you lie
People have to trust you to be their friend
Our social system is based on our ability to trust each other

questions.title: Item 15. Candle
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What does this saying mean? “It’s better to light a candle than to complain about the darkness.”

General concept: In times of difficulty, it is better to be proactive and attempt to improve a situation than to passively accept or complain about it

answers.html: Don’t give up; Keep trying
Stop (whining, complaining); Don’t (whine, complain)
If it’s dark, all you have to do is light a candle; People are happier in brightness than in shadows; [Provides literal interpretation]
Candles are better than darkness
Go with the flow; Keep on rolling; [Provides unrelated saying]
When the going gets tough, the tough get going; Actions speak louder than words; Don’t sweat the small stuff; [Provides analogous proverb or saying]
Don’t feel sorry for yourself
Focus on the positive instead of the negative; Be (happy with, thankful for) what you have
Do something; Take action; Keep moving forward; Don’t procrastinate
You can make things better
Don’t (dwell, focus) on bad things
You are in control
Nothing will change if you don’t do something about it
Don’t complain about bad situations, (improve, work your way out of) them
Don’t let your (frustration, anger) stop you from making things better
Better to fix a problem than complain about it
When things are hard, you have the power to make things better
Instead of feeling sorry for yourself when things go wrong, do something to make it better
Stop complaining and do something about it
It’s better to solve your own problems than to (wait for, rely on) others to fix them; Don’t (rely, depend) on others to (fix your problems, make things better for you)
Don’t just sit there, do something about it

questions.title: Item 16. Cheat
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Why is it bad to cheat on a test?

General concept: Recognition that cheating is unfair to students who earn their grades through honest efforts, or that cheating is ultimately self-defeating because the material is not learned and there is an academic consequence

answers.html: Might get (caught, in trouble)
Don’t depend on someone else; Don’t count on other people
You only cheat yourself
You will get a bad grade
Cheaters never win
Person you’re cheating from could (get mad, have wrong answers)
Because you (forgot to study, don’t know the answers)
It’s (mean, not nice, bad)
It’s against the rules
It’s (unfair, not fair)
If you get caught, you could (get a bad grade, get suspended, lose the teacher’s trust); [Describes specific and current academic consequence]
It’s (lying, dishonest)
Won’t learn
It’s unethical
You’ll have to keep cheating
People might ask you to do something you really can’t do
Won’t get the grade you deserve
The teacher won’t know how much you know; The teacher wants to see what you know, not what your neighbor knows
Won’t learn because you (don’t know the material, didn’t study)
You only cheat yourself because you don’t learn the material
Not fair to the people who (studied, worked hard on the assignment)
You won’t learn and could (fail the test, get suspended, make a zero)
If you cheat, you will fall behind in school and have to keep cheating
You won’t be able to pass college classes

questions.title: Item 17. Stress
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
How can stress be a good thing?

General concept: Recognition that stress is an important motivator and can lead to positive outcomes

answers.html: Makes you (prepare, get ready) for (tests, speeches); Makes you (study, do homework)
You need stress
It makes you think
Lets you (eat candy, take a bath)
It will go away if you (wait, hold on)
Stress can make you (sick, angry, feel bad, anxious); [Provides negative aspect of stress]
Stress is (normal, part of life)
So you do something; Makes you (act, do things); [Refers to actions without reference to being new or challenging]
Stress has led to (discoveries, inventions, advancements)
Keeps you from being lazy
(Pushes, Pressures) you
Makes you (work, do things) (harder, faster, better)
Makes you (better, stronger)
(Tells, Shows) you what’s important; Helps you focus
(Prepares you, Gets you ready) for (something, things); Prepares you for life
(Tells you, Shows you, Lets you know) that you’re working hard
Learn from it
Reminds you to (relax, calm down, slow down)
Makes you (plan, stop and think about what you’re doing)
Makes you think more about what’s important
Without stress you can grow (complacent, bored)
Makes you try things; So you try something new
Stress (pushes, pressures) people to (grow, learn, adapt) more than they would without it; Makes you do things you wouldn’t before
(Makes, Causes) people to (come up with new ideas, think of different ways to do something)
It (pushes, pressures) you to (work harder, get something done, do better); Sometimes you do your best work under pressure
(Motivates, Inspires) you; Motivates you to (succeed, do a good job)
Makes you work harder and (better, you get better results)
It (pushes, pressures) you to succeed

questions.title: §Item 18. Technology
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What are some problems with rapid changes in science and technology?

answers.text: Evolving too fast; Too many changes too fast
Keep having to (change, learn new things)
Causes job loss; Replaces people with robots
Could become dependent on technology
Old technology (leaves, is gone) too quickly
The more (harm, bad) we can do; We can do more bad things
We could (destroy the environment, cause pollution)
Change is bad; Technology makes things worse
New technology is lower in quality
We would be getting ahead of ourselves; Consequences may not have been thought of
If we go too fast, we might forget important things we learned a long time ago
Fast advances in technology can have glitches; We can make mistakes if we go too fast
Create things that are controversial; Could create harmful things by accident
Overreliance on technology can cause people to (have worse social skills, miss what’s going on in the world)
Technology can do jobs that people used to do, so some people will lose their jobs
The world isn’t ready for some changes

answerGroups.answersExplanation: Recognition that rapid change may create unforeseen consequences and reduce consideration of past experiences
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Response reflects one of the general concepts

answers.text: Don’t have enough time to learn things; Not everyone can keep up
Waste of money; We waste a lot of money and time (keeping up, maintaining, buying) new technology
Facts and knowledge change too quickly; Difficult to keep information current
Hard for some people to change if they aren’t in school
Need new (hardware, equipment); You buy something new and then there’s something newer; Things get outdated fast
People lose their jobs if they don’t have new skills

answerGroups.answersExplanation: Recognition that rapid changes create difficulties in maintaining current knowledge and technology
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Response reflects both of the general concepts

scoreList.label: Response reflects one of the general concepts
Response reflects both of the general concepts

questions.title: Item 19. Guests
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What does this saying mean? “No guests at home, no hosts abroad.”

General concept: How you treat people determines how you will be treated in return

answers.html: (Don’t be mean, Be good, Be polite) to your guests
If you don’t let other people in, they won’t let you in
If you don’t (visit, go), don’t expect them to (visit, invite you, be a host)
If you don’t invite people to your house, you’ll never be invited to theirs
If you have people over, you can (visit them later, travel to foreign countries); [Provides literal interpretation]
Nobody is (at home, there)
If you’re not a good guest, don’t expect a good host
(Be nice, Don’t be mean) to people if you (don’t want to be alone, want to have friends)
If you turn people away, you will (be lonely, isolate yourself)
It’s the (Golden Rule, ethic of reciprocity)
Being open to other people makes people open to you
Do unto others as you would have them do unto you; Treat others as you want to be treated; [Provides analogous proverb or saying]
You should be (nice, kind, friendly, good) to other people
People will be mean to you unless you’re nice to them
If you treat people well, they will treat you well
How you treat others affects how others treat you
If you’re not (nice, friendly) to people, people won’t be (nice, friendly) to you
You can’t expect to be treated well if you aren’t nice to others

reverseRule.noSkipMsg: If suspected of having an intellectual disability or low cognitive ability
